abstracts.cdata!:
The Fourth Highway Project in Lesotho
            was achieved. Bank staff and officials of the Government
            involved in the implementation of the project enjoyed an
            amiable and highly professional working relationship. The
            project benefited from the high level of continuity in the
            supervisory staff assigned to it as well as from the vast
            professional experience of the individuals. The Loan
            Agreement provided adequate guidance in project management
            and implementation. There were no distinguishable delays in
            the submission of withdrawal applications. However, this was
            not the case regarding the submission of both audit and
            consultant progress reports. The Fourth Highway Project was,
            to a large extent, coordinated by expatriates due to the
            whole scale movement of local engineers to the Lesotho
            Highlands Water Project (LHWP) and the private sector. As a
            result the few local engineers that remained behind did not
            get as much exposure as these expatriates due to some work
            exigencies in some other projects and activities of the Road
            Branch (RB). Perhaps the Government of Lesotho (GOL) would
            be well advised to try to address the problem of the
            unabating movement of Basotho engineers from the civil service.
